ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to fluently use the past tense and also the future and pres subjunctive tenses and gained skills with practical application.
More grammar, vocabulary, and different mediums of art (art, literature, movies, short films, scripts)
A greater understanding of spanish vocabulary, grammar, speaking skills, and cultural concepts.

I learned a couple interesting facts about Latin American culture, cities, and natural spaces, but my Spanish did not improve as much as I would've liked. We spent almost no time reviewing grammar, and although a lot of class time was dedicated to speaking in Spanish, there was almost never any feedback when I mis-conjugated a verb or used the wrong word, so I couldn't really learn from these exercises.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was run very well and I think the grading and assignment format was positive and fair.

Strengths: The professor was exceptionally accessible
Weaknesses: you had to put in the effort outside of the people sitting next to you to get to know one another.

Meeting every day (except for asynchronous Wednesdays) and having a large amount of writing homework definitely helped me improve my Spanish communication abilities! Also, in-class discussions, which focused on a large variety of topics, GREATLY improved my conversational skills. However, the supersite homework, which was our sole manner of learning the grammatical concepts tested on exams, wasn't very helpful (harsh grading), and sometimes, many of the homework assignments were insanely time-consuming and felt like busywork. Additionally, sometimes I wished that group project members were assigned randomly so that I could work with/talk to different students, rather than merely those who sat next to me! This class was difficult, but very rewarding in the end.

The asynchronous day is essential - having each Wednesday to catch up and review made a world of difference to me. I didn't feel that I gained anything significant from many of the classroom activities - it is difficult to hold a large group or small group conversations about relatively abstract topics because I often didn't know the words I needed to describe something like "urban sprawl." For me, the biggest challenge I faced while studying Spanish was correctly conjugating the verbs, and we spent almost no time practicing this in class - in some ways, I felt my ability to conjugate verbs regressed from L2.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would if they are looking to get experience learning and improving a language ability to be able to speak with natives and understand speech and writing of the language.
Yes! The content is interesting, but sometimes it does feel like busy work. If you pace it correctly and make the effort to go see the professors during office hours, you will be good.

Yes, if you're cognizant of the fact that the workload is quite high and time-consuming! Additionally, if you're coming straight from high school Spanish and haven't had much experience speaking in Spanish in the past, you'll have to quickly adapt to the "seminar style" of Yale spanish classes. Overall, though, L3 spanish was very rewarding and I'd recommend it for students willing to put in the work!

I think there are a lot of compelling reasons to study Spanish, so I'm glad I studied Spanish at Yale, but in my opinion the structure of this class is more often an impediment to learning Spanish than a guide.
